channel.title: BBC News - Technology

item.title: Kardashians deny faking Roblox sex tape scene
item.description: Questions are being asked about a scene in The Kardashians, when Kim's son finds a sex tape ad on Roblox.

item.title: CNN streaming service to shut a month after launch
item.description: It comes as Netflix has reported a plunge in subscribers in the face of stiff competition from rivals.

item.title: Actors launch campaign against AI 'show stealers'
item.description: Equity, the performing arts workers union, says actors need protection from computer-generated substitutes.

item.title: Binance crypto exchange forced to scrap swastika-like emoji
item.description: Binance said the situation was "really embarrassing", after Twitter users noticed the similarity.

item.title: Tesla profits soar as customers pay more
item.description: Elon Musk's Tesla has raised prices for its electric cars as it faces higher costs.

item.title: Netflix hints at password sharing crackdown as subscribers fall
item.description: The firm needs to sign up new subscribers after losing 200,000 in the first quarter of the year.

item.title: US bans anti-satellite missile tests
item.description: US Vice-President Harris says US will stop testing missiles designed to destroy spacecraft in orbit.

item.title: Highway Code: Watching TV in self-driving cars to be allowed
item.description: Mobile phone use while driving will remain illegal, as changes to the Highway Code are announced.

item.title: Apple staff make bid for first union at a US store
item.description: Employees must get signatures from 30% of staff at New York's Grand Central Station for a union election.

item.title: No 10 network targeted with spyware, says group
item.description: Researchers say they warned UK officials about being targeted, but the software's makers deny the claims.

item.title: Twitter board takes action to fight Musk bid
item.description: The so-called "poison pill" measure is in response to Elon Musk's $43bn cash buyout offer.

item.title: North Korean hackers target gamers in $615m crypto heist - US
item.description: Crypto worth at least $615 million was stolen from players of popular online game Axie Infinity.

item.title: Child sex abuse victims want Online Safety Bill strengthened
item.description: Charities say online predators increasingly live-stream, an area not covered by the bill.

item.title: Three arrests over unofficial Club Penguin site
item.description: Disney launch copyright claim against latest unauthorised version of the defunct children's game.

item.title: NFT of Jack Dorsey's first tweet struggles to sell
item.description: Malaysia-based Sina Estavi has been offered just a small fraction of the $2.9m he paid for the tweet.

item.title: How facial recognition is identifying the dead in Ukraine
item.description: A controversial facial recognition platform has been used more than 1,000 times by Ukrainian officials.

item.title: US cryptocurrency expert jailed for helping North Korea evade sanctions
item.description: Virgil Griffith was sentenced to five years and three months in prison by a court in New York.

item.title: Shanghai lockdown: iPhone maker halts operations at China sites
item.description: Taiwanese firm Pegatron is latest manufacturer to halt operations because of the Shanghai lockdown.

item.title: Elon Musk 'not sure' his takeover bid for Twitter will be successful
item.description: The Tesla boss claims he has a 'Plan B' if his offer, which values the firm at $43bn, is rejected.

item.title: Raidforums marketplace shut down in global operation
item.description: A forum which allowed criminals access to stolen personal data - for a fee - has been taken down.

item.title: Ukrainian power grid 'lucky' to withstand Russian cyber-attack
item.description: Cyber experts say the malicious software used points to notorious military attackers.

item.title: Self-driving car stopped by San Francisco police
item.description: Video shows how law enforcers are having to adapt to a new era of autonomous vehicles.

item.title: Elon Musk will not join Twitter board, says boss
item.description: Tesla's chief executive was due to join the social media platform's board after buying a 9.2% stake.

item.title: Google removes apps for secretly copying phone numbers
item.description: More than a dozen apps were taken out of its Play Store for harvesting users' phone numbers.

item.title: Gen Z calling for more honesty on social media, experts say
item.description: Analysts say young people now expect to see greater levels of realism in their feeds.

item.title: Mystery of alleged Chinese hack on eve of Ukraine invasion
item.description: A western intelligence official believes the aim was espionage - but questions remain.

item.title: Ronin Network bailed out by crypto giant Binance after hack
item.description: Hacked cryptocurrency and games company says its customers will now be reimbursed.

item.title: Nano ink solar cells allow tech to charge in any light
item.description: Custom nano inks allow solar cells to be made to any shape and can use ambient light to power devices.

item.title: Cuddly toy reviews used for headphones on Amazon
item.description: Sellers are boosting ratings of electronics with reviews for completely different products, Which? finds.

item.title: Elon Musk to answer Twitter staff questions
item.description: Employees will be able quiz the entrepreneur as he joins the board of Twitter, after share purchase.

item.title: Instagram: Presenter Rachel Riley received series of porn messages
item.description: The Center for Countering Digital Hate found abuse in the Instagram DMs of five high-profile females.

item.title: Twitter confirms it is working on an edit button
item.description: It comes after new board member Elon Musk asked his followers if they wanted the feature.

item.title: Amazon secures rockets for broadband project
item.description: It has booked 83 launches for its low earth orbit satellite internet system Project Kuiper.

item.title: Twitter moves to limit Russian government accounts
item.description: The platform has taken action to limit more than 300 Kremlin accounts, including President Putin's.

item.title: What are Elon Musk's plans for Twitter?
item.description: The Tesla founder has become the social network's biggest single shareholder, and a board member.

item.title: Hydra: How German police dismantled Russian darknet site
item.description: German police say illegal sales on the site amounted to at least £1bn a year

item.title: Broadband firms 'must do more to promote social tariffs'
item.description: The culture secretary says suppliers must do more to promote discounted rates to low-income homes.

item.title: Cryptocurrency: UK Treasury to regulate some stablecoins
item.description: Treasury Minister John Glen says "stablecoins" could be used as a means of payment.

item.title: The Works forced to shut some shops after cyber-attack
item.description: The retailer said that five of its 526 shops have temporarily been shut since the attack last week.

item.title: Ukraine war: Fortnite maker Epic Games raises $144m (£110m) to help victims
item.description: Fundraising campaigns by games companies have raised millions of dollars for humanitarian causes.

item.title: Electric hydroplane boat: ‘It feels like we’re flying’
item.description: With the hull out of the water, the craft uses 80% less power than a boat would conventionally need.

item.title: Ukraine war scams: Cybercriminals stole my identity
item.description: Scammers are using emotionally charged tricks in a bid to steal online donations.

item.title: Former Twitter exec questions seriousness of Musk offer
item.description: Vivian Schiller, who used to work there, tells Newsnight Elon Musk enjoys "throwing bombs" on Twitter.

item.title: This plug socket tells you if your energy is green
item.description: A power socket that helps you save electricity and tells you if it's from renewable sources.

item.title: Prince Charles visits sustainable aviation laboratory
item.description: Prince Charles meets staff from the Whittle Laboratory to learn about sustainable aviation.

item.title: Why Argentina is embracing cryptocurrency
item.description: The nation that has seen economic trauma is open to the possibility of alternative money like Bitcoin.

item.title: Are there affordable ways to cut your heating bill?
item.description: Alternatives to gas and oil heating are becoming more popular but are still expensive.

item.title: Crypto boss says fraudsters have 'special place in hell'
item.description: An executive at one of the largest cryptocurrency exchanges hits out at scammers who target the vulnerable.

item.title: Streaming is driving a 'golden age' for Indian drama
item.description: India's 30 streaming services want to reach 60 million households meaning a lot more work for actors.

item.title: The microchip implants that let you pay with your hand
item.description: You can now get a payment chip injected beneath your skin, turning you into a human bank card.

item.title: Why France's daily baguette is costing so much dough
item.description: Every part of the cost of the daily staple is rising - flour, electricity, gas and wages.

item.title: Bafta Games Awards 2022: 'Plucky underdogs' go up against hit titles
item.description: Hit titles go up against games made by four people during the pandemic "because they were bored".

item.title: Does it matter if we know where our food comes from?
item.description: Increasingly sophisticated tech tells us more than ever about our food's journey from farm to fork.

item.title: Pet cloning is getting more popular despite the cost
item.description: The controversial process of cloning your dog or cat is growing more popular, despite its high cost.

item.title: Chip shortage: Has Europe's plan arrived too late?
item.description: The European Union is investing billions of euros in developing a world-beating chip industry.

item.title: Can tech help you to manage the cost of living?
item.description: Personal finance apps are everywhere but are they useful if you are already in debt or on low wages.

item.title: Beating noise pollution with smart tech
item.description: A growing number of firms are offering solutions to cut the excessive noise that's harming our health

item.title: Electric cars: Five big questions answered
item.description: The electric car revolution is speeding up but what do buyers really want to know?

item.title: Why patients are flocking to India for surgery
item.description: There has been a sharp growth in medical tourism to India but the sector needs better regulation.

item.title: Not smart but clever? The return of 'dumbphones'
item.description: Why sales of very basic mobile phones, without apps and internet connection, are increasing.

item.title: How a jetpack design helped create a flying motorbike
item.description: The developers of a powerful mini aircraft hope it will be used by the armed forces.

item.title: The popular apps aiming to tame the chaos of family life
item.description: How tech is helping young families and couples regain their busy social lives after Covid.

item.title: The innovative surfing tech making waves
item.description: The sport of surfing is modernising, using technology to offer bigger, better and safer thrills.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war: A warm hug meant that war had begun
item.description: Why so many Ukrainians are determined to keep on working through the conflict.
